When applying the mattress cover pull the mattress completely off the bed frame and pull up blankets, sheets, pillows, and your personal laundry and put that through the wash. Why do this? This is gentler than blowing or snorting.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>why would locking pliers work where normal pliers failed me?
As the name suggests, they lock. You tighten the screw up over the thing you're trying to twist, unclick them, tighten the screw up a bit more, then click them on again (it will be significantly harder to do this, because to shut them you're now bending the metal cross-brace of the pliers). This makes them bite it like a motherfucker, and not let go.

You can then turn the pliers without needing to apply any force to hold them closed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318650
All SSDs do that though: they write to a small "nursery" area of (MLC) flash that's treated as SLC, then in the background they clear the nursery out into the slower MLC. Every SSD that's not pure SLC will slow after enough sustained writing, that's just how they work.

The behaviour you're seeing in the graph has to be the disk running out of SLC blocks: there's no way it has several GB of RAM inside the controller chip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318650
To clarify, there's no real difference between SLC and MLC cells, so you can use a MLC as either. If you treat it as SLC, you just check if there's one or zero, which is pretty unambiguous and therefore fast. If it's MLC, you have to measure the actual charge in the cell, and decide if it's a one or a two or a zero or a three (or even more possible numbers if you're storing three or even four bits in a cell), and that takes a bit more time, but what really hurts is filling a cell precisely so it holds a thirteen and not a twelve, then going back and making absolutely sure you wrote a thirteen, and fixing it if you didn't.

The decision to use a block as MLC or SLC is made by the controller, but as QLC holds four times as much as SLC, it obviously costs four times as much to make the disk entirely out of SLC. So there's a design tradeoff, and obviously more expensive drives will have more total cells and use more as SLC cache and spares, and therefore they'll be faster and last longer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1317652
That looks like nylon, so I would weld it:
- get some donor material that's exactly the same type of plastic (a no-name brand zipper, for example)
- get a cheap-ass temperature-controlled soldering iron off ebay. It has to be temperature controlled, that's the key to this operation
- set it to 300 degrees, and you should be able to push the plastic about like it's warm chocolate. Stir it all together so there's no gaps, build the hole up so there's excess plastic in every direction, then sand it back to the correct shape
If you want to definitely get nylon, you can get nylon washers.

No it's not, nylon melts at 500°F, so the idea that you could melt it at 300°F is ridiculous.

These $10 irons aren't particularly accurate, so load it up with the widest bit it comes with, start off at 250°C, and if no melty, turn it up to 300°C. Practice on something you don't care about first. Work at as low a temperature as possible, it's more important that you not burn it than you go fast.

posts.com:
You know those glossy, ultra-slick action movies from the mid-90s
to early 2000s where they didn't care for realistic physics or
whatever, they just wanted it to look awesome? Give me some
recommendations for those kind of movies.

Criteria - REQUIRED:
- kickass action that doesn't give two shits about being realistic
- Dark gritty cities
- Guns, LOTS of guns
- weapons that might be made of chrome
- really unique weapon, costume and set designs
- Secret organizations

NOT 100% Required
- Supernatural element and evil inhuman monsters, possibly with a conspiracy or mystery to solve
- good looking protagonist, possibly laden in something with leather
- May or may NOT have had Patrick Tatopoulos in production in some way or other
- heavy metal, hip-hop or techno soundtrack (DEFINITELY not required, but helps)
- Made before 2010 (NOT required, as several entries below will show you)

posts.name: ESSENTIALS
posts.com:
List so far

ESSENTIALS
1 - Alien series (protozoa for this kind of shit, as is the Terminator series...at least the first 3)
2 - Blade (THE codifier for everything on this series; same with the Matrix)
3 - Resident Evil film series, directed by Paul WS Anderson as well as
4 - Underworld film series
5 - Doom 2005 with The Rock and Karl Urban
6 - Ultraviolet by Kurt Wimmer with Milla Jovovich

posts.name: SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL
posts.com:
List so far

SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL

1 - Nemesis 1992 (remember when Selene in Underworld escaped the Lycans by blasting the floor into Swiss cheese? This film did it first. No joke, and it's AWESOME!)
2 - The Crow
3 - Uwe Boll's House of the Dead and Alone in the Dark (despite their reception they could when you actually watch them)
4 - Equilibrium (also directed by Kurt Wimmer)
5 - Priest 2011
6 - Hardcore Henry (minus horror element, fits the criteria above to a fucking T)
7 - I, Frankenstein (made by the guy who made Underworld and was SUPPOSED to have a crossover with it but, well, that fell through for one reason or another
8 - Hellboy and Hellboy 2: The Golden Army

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: POSSIBLY
posts.com:

POSSIBLY


1 - Van Helsing with Hugh Jackman
2 - League of Extraordinary Gentlemen with Sean Connery

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317957
>How common are they?
I wish I knew. It's a very potent kind of malware. I haven't heard of any cases that were actually spread like viruses. Maybe it's more suited for elaborate rootkits made by state actors and used on high level targets.
>Can they be detected?
In theory, it could evade detection completely. In practice, you'd probably need a special tool to detect specific brands of malware.
>HDDs, SD cards, USBs
You mean like infect them, and spread the infection when connecting the storage device to another PC? They have microprocessors and communicate with the host PC. In theory they can get infected. But it sounds extremely unlikely. Not only would the malware have to attack many firmware revisions from many vendors, find and use open security holes, but it would also need to have a way to infect another host PC back using the infected HDD firmware. Probably a bit more likely: malware modifying files on storage devices you've connected to the PC. But even a normal virus can do that. Aren't USB memory sticks a pretty common vectors of infection? Like there's an infected exe on it, and Windows autorun does the rest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1317983
>I've actually abandoned my pc due to suspicions and I'm getting a new one,
It would be very difficult indeed for even a fully controlled, internet-connected, hostile storage device to own windows 11.

Assuming the BIOS is uncompromised, Secure Boot will prevent the storage device from tampering with any of the unencrypted code in the boot chain, the TPM will unlock only if the unencrypted code executes as normal, and then the key from the TPM is required to access the real windows partition that's fully encrypted. A hostile storage device would be SOL, the worst it could do is deny service by not writing what it's been asked to, and maybe some extremely superficial traffic analysis, along the lines of "this guy is using the computer/not using the compiler/using the program that reads sector #285747273 again".

Hostile BIOS update, absolutely. The root of trust is the BIOS*, so it can fundamentally undermine Secure Boot by surreptitiously using a hostile key. The TPM would notice this though, and Bitlocker would go into recovery mode the first boot after the BIOS got compromised. If the user entered the Bitlocker recovery key though, the BIOS could even use SMM to capture it and store it in the BIOS forever, giving it easy access to the encrypted partitions.


* on some Xeons, the root of trust is the CPU, but that's not popular in consumer processors because it ties the CPU to the motherboard forever the first time you boot.

Thank you for trying my question. The goal is as few pixels and colors as possible. The reason is because of how fast Maid Space numbers get bigger. If you draw a maid, the Maid Address for her is somewhere between zero and the number of colors you used raised to a power equal to the number of pixels in the image, minus one. So counting can take a long time and make a huge book, or be beyond practical limitations of the computer.

Imagine you need four colors and drew the maid in a eight by six image. A radix four, eight by six Maid Space counts from zero to seventy-nine octillion two hundred twenty-eight septillion one hundred sixty-two sextillion five hundred fourteen quintillion two hundred sixty-four quadrillion three hundred thirty seven trillion five hundred ninety-three billion five hundred fourty-three million nine hundred fifty thousand three hundred thirty four.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318459
What you have is not really an opus audio file but an opus audio stream inside an mp4 container (with no video).
I don't know what tools you used to rip and mux that shit, but you should take a look at the config/parameters as for why it gives you an mp4 instead of a plain .opus file.
So just rip the audio using whatever, ffmpeg for example:
ffmpeg.exe -i jm98jf.mp4 -vn -acodec copy jm98jf.opus
and then you'll normally be able to use it as you intend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318419
>how [I have literally no spare drives]
Boot to linux and
smartctl -a
badblocks -n
The "-n" is important, it tests every block on the device but first makes a copy of the data and puts it back afterwards. If the "reallocated sector count" is non-zero before you begin, or it increases because of the test, the device is toast. Whilst "-n" is supposedly "non-destructive", it can push a dodgy device over the cliff, and you might lose the specific sector it fails on if the device isn't writing reliably, so back up everything you care about first.
>how [I have spare drives]
dd onto a new/known-good device and see if the problem goes away

>>1318402
>here's the disk overview
That's clearly GPT, so your boot is clearly UEFI (as you do not have an MBR to boot). So >>1317949
>If I go to the BIOS and change it to Legacy, Windows will still go into black screen, however the recovery menu works in Legacy.
is a red herring, you should be set to UEFI with Secure Boot on and CSM off.
>>1318402
>I think the problem lies in the EFI boot pratrition.
Then erase everything on it and recreate it with bcdboot.

diskpart
select vol 7
format quick fs=fat32
assign letter=s:
exit
bcdboot c:\windows /s s:

Obviously checking the drive letters and volume numbers is your job, no complaining on 4chan.

I was reading it on Mangadex, but I forgot to bookmark it. I think it had the Psychological, Romance, Mystery, Tragedy tags, but I keep searching with various combinations and can't seem to find it.

All I remember is something about MC and his childhood friend walking home from school one day, I think her birthday was coming up and he needed a gift idea ASAP.

At some point he sees a woman drowning and goes to help her, but she says something bad will happen to MC now that he's getting involved with her. I think she advises MC to buy a four-leaf clover charm for good luck.

Then, much later, I think MC gets run over by a train, but the girl he rescued from drowning earlier somehow alters time/reality and takes his place. MC survives and vows to figure out how she died, because (I think) somebody pushed them onto the rails in both instances.

Trying to install xbox live redistributable on my PC to play an old GFWL game. No, there's no other workaround, or I'd be using it.

I have had everything working up until very recently. Today I get errors saying certain xlive DLLs are missing. These are populated by the windows xbox live redistributable, which seemingly uninstalled itself from my PC and won't allow me to reinstall it.

I run xliveredist.msi and it just instantly closes without doing anything. I try "repair" or "uninstall" and it says "only valid for software already installed". I ran this game three weeks ago and it was fine. It seems this and some other DLLs just removed themselves from my computer recently.

Machine is on a new SSD so it can't be disk failure. Aside from downloading some old TV show MKVs from archive I haven't done anything too weird.

Biggest headache source is probably that I swapped mobos a few months ago. My original mobo died and I had to buy a refurb, and I'm not 100% that it's any good, but my PC is 9 years old and so I'm not sure what else to do there (I have a win7 install and I'm hesitant to try and move it to a new machine and have to re-license it or whatever stupid shit MS might push on me). Still, weird shit has been happening since then, so maybe that's the root cause. No idea why that would happen or what I can do about it though. Any advice on moving forward is appreciated.

posts.com: oh, and I verified that in event viewer, shit says xliveredist installed with no issues, so not sure what the deal is, the installer just seems to do nothing and exit with success.
